title: C04-1128

sentences.text: While sentence extraction as an approach to summarization has been shown to work in documents of certain genres , because of the conversational nature of email communication where utterances are made in relation to one made previously , sentence extraction may not capture the necessary segments of dialogue that would make a summary coherent .
In this paper , we present our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization .
We show that various features based on the structure of email-threads can be used to improve upon lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing .

kg2text: This paper presents research on the detection of question-answer pairs, which is essential for the task of email summarization. The detection of question-answer pairs is aimed at enhancing the coherence of summaries generated from email conversations. Various features based on the structure of email-threads can be utilized to improve upon the lexical similarity of discourse segments, thereby enhancing the identification of question-answer pairs. Additionally, these features can also improve question-answer pairing, which is a structured relationship between questions and their corresponding answers. The task of email summarization encompasses the detection of question-answer pairs, and it is a broader term that relates to the overall process of summarization. Furthermore, the structure of email-threads is foundational to understanding how email communications are organized, and it has a broader term, email-threads, which refers to the sequences of messages exchanged. Lexical similarity of discourse segments, which measures the similarity in word choice between segments, also has a broader term, lexical similarity. Overall, this paper contributes to the understanding of how various features and processes interact to enhance email summarization.

Sentence extraction is a method that falls under the broader category of summarization, which aims to condense information while retaining essential meaning. In the realm of email communication, this process is influenced by the conversational nature of email exchanges, which is characterized by interactive dialogues that affect how information is summarized. Additionally, question-answer pairs, which are structured relationships between questions and their corresponding answers, are often detected within email conversations. The effectiveness of these pairs can be enhanced by understanding the structure of email threads, as lexical similarity is based on this structure and is related to discourse segments within the conversation. Furthermore, sentence extraction has been shown to be effective in various documents of certain genres, which are a subset of the broader category of documents. Ultimately, a well-crafted summary would ensure coherence, making it easier for readers to grasp the main points of the original text.
